Url.Title: Introducing Sage SalesLogix
Url.Abstract: Introducing Sage SalesLogix for Web Sage SalesLogix manages all aspects of the sales cycle over the Web. In addition to tracking contacts, accounts, leads, opportunities, tickets and activities, users have access to tools for reporting, automating processes, and creating e-mails, faxes, and letters using mail merge. With additional security permissions, you may also have access to administrative tools for user, team, department, and pick list management.

Url.Title: Contacting Sage
Url.Abstract: Contact Information This documentation was developed by Sage SalesLogix User Assistance. For content revisions, questions, or comments, contact the Sage SalesLogix writers at saleslogix.techpubs@sage.com.

Url.Title: What's New In This Release
Url.Abstract: What's New In This Release Sage SalesLogix Web Client contains the following updates: Web Client Version 8.0

Url.Title: Using the Help System
Url.Abstract: Using the Help System The Help systems available with Sage SalesLogix contain explanations of features and functionality, with links to related subjects.

Url.Title: Assumptions and Conventions
Url.Abstract: Assumptions and Conventions This online guide assumes that you have a working knowledge of your browser (for example, using a search engine or entering a URL) and fundamental operating system concepts (for example, clicking and dragging, file navigation, and so on). If you are unfamiliar with these concepts, see the Help files available for your browser.

Url.Title: New User Tips
Url.Abstract: New User Tips If this is your first time using the Sage SalesLogix Web Client or Sage SalesLogix Customer Portal, keep the following tips in mind:

Url.Title: Getting Started with the Sage SalesLogix Web Client
Url.Abstract: Getting Started with the Sage SalesLogix Web Client The Sage SalesLogix Web Client helps you manage all aspects of the sales cycle over the Web. This topic includes links to commonly performed tasks and overview topics to help you begin to use the Sage SalesLogix Web Client.

Url.Title: Logging on to Sage SalesLogix
Url.Abstract: Logging on to the Sage SalesLogix Web Client Sage SalesLogix Web Client Before you begin, locate your User ID and password. If you do not have this information, contact your system administrator.

Url.Title: Editing User Options
Url.Abstract: Editing User Options Sage SalesLogix provides tools to allow you to modify some parts of the interface so that you can work in the way that suits you best. User Options allow you to set specific preferences for such features as the view that appears when you start the Sage SalesLogix Web Client and Alerts. Your settings that you enter are recorded for you and are not visible to other Sage SalesLogix users. Some options are shared between the Sage SalesLogix Client and Sage SalesLogix Web Client.

Url.Title: Related Documentation
Url.Abstract: Related Documentation In addition to this Help system, the following printed and online documentation is available:

Url.Title: Understanding Your Workspace
Url.Abstract: Understanding the Sage SalesLogix Web Client Workspace Sage SalesLogix Web Client The workspace is the area where various views appear in the main Sage SalesLogix Web Client.

Url.Title: Managing Resources
Url.Abstract: Managing Resources The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using the Resource Detail view
Url.Abstract: Using the Resource Detail view The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Managing Qualifications
Url.Abstract: Managing Qualifications The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using the Qualification Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Qualification Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: A New Employee Needs Access to SalesLogix
Url.Abstract: A New Employee Needs Access to Sage SalesLogix The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: A User Leaves or No Longer Requires SalesLogix
Url.Abstract: A User Leaves or No Longer Requires Sage SalesLogix The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: A User Takes Extended Leave
Url.Abstract: A User Takes Extended Leave The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: A User Returns From Extended Leave
Url.Abstract: A User Returns From Extended Leave The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: User Detail View
Url.Abstract: User Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Understanding Users
Url.Abstract: Understanding Users Users are the people that can access your Sage SalesLogix database. Each user has a profile that defines information such as the user name, title, manager, team membership, department membership, and security access.

Url.Title: Using the Users List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Users List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Adding a User
Url.Abstract: Adding a User The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Activating or Deactivating a User Login
Url.Abstract: Activating or Deactivating a User Login You can set the login status of a user as active or inactive. New users are active by default. When a user login is inactive, they cannot access the Sage SalesLogix database. However, an inactive user’s profile is not deleted and a license remains assigned to that user.

Url.Title: Changing a User's Profile
Url.Abstract: Changing a User's Profile The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Changing Other Users' Passwords - Admin
Url.Abstract: Changing a Password (Administrator) You can change a user's password in the Users view and through user Options.

Url.Title: Other Calendars Tab
Url.Abstract: Other Calendars Tab Use the Other Calendars tab on the User Detail view to set permission rights for a user to view and modify other user’s calendars. By default, users do not have access to any other user’s calendars. When a user's calendar is added to another user's profile, view access rights are automatically enabled.

Url.Title: Working with Teams
Url.Abstract: Working with Teams Teams can consist of users, departments, and other teams. You might create teams based on region, territory, type of account, or department.

Url.Title: Creating a Team
Url.Abstract: Creating a Team The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Adding Team Members
Url.Abstract: Adding Team Members The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Removing or Replacing Team Members
Url.Abstract: Removing or Replacing Team Members You can remove team members or replace one user with another on a team.

Url.Title: Creating a Department
Url.Abstract: Creating a Department The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Pick List Detail View
Url.Abstract: Pick List Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: What are Pick Lists?
Url.Abstract: What are Pick Lists? A pick list is a list of values that you can select from when entering data in a field. For example, in a City field, the user can select from a list of cities rather than typing in a value. Tell me more...

Url.Title: Adding a Pick List
Url.Abstract: Adding a Pick List The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Managing Items in a Pick List
Url.Abstract: Managing Items in a Pick List You can edit a pick list by adding a new item, editing an existing item, or deleting an item from the pick list.

Url.Title: Role Detail View
Url.Abstract: Role Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: What are Roles and Secured Actions?
Url.Abstract: What are Roles and Secured Actions? A role determines what functionality a user can access in the Web Client. Roles use secured actions to control access to user interface elements such as pages, menus, menu items, toolbars, and buttons. When you control access to individual user interface elements, you can control access to actions such as editing, deleting, or printing. Current secured elements are all user interface elements giving access to accounts, contacts, and opportunities.

Url.Title: Creating a Role
Url.Abstract: Creating a Role The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using Accounting Integration
Url.Abstract: Using Accounting Integration This feature is only available if your administrator has configured Accounting Integration.

Url.Title: Introducing Integration
Url.Abstract: Introducing Integration Accounting Integration allows you to share information between Sage SalesLogix and any accounting system that supports Sage CRM ERP Contract. Sage SalesLogix Web Client users can view open sales orders, customer invoices, customer payments, open invoices, and their corresponding details.

Url.Title: Configuring Accounting Integration
Url.Abstract: Configuring Accounting Integration Complete the following tasks to configure Accounting Integration. If multi-currency is enabled, ensure Sage SalesLogix and your accounting system have the same base currency.

Url.Title: Accounting Integration Detail View
Url.Abstract: Accounting Integration Detail View Use the Accounting Integration Detail view to configure the connections between Sage SalesLogix and your accounting system(s).

Url.Title: Configuring the Accounting Integration Synchronization Service
Url.Abstract: Configuring the Accounting Integration Synchronization Service The Accounting Integration Synchronization Service (Sage SalesLogix SData Sync Service) allows data transfer between Sage SalesLogix and your accounting system. The service must be started and set to run as automatic.

Url.Title: Using Check for Duplicates
Url.Abstract: Using Check for Duplicates The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: What Are Contacts?
Url.Abstract: What Are Contacts? Contacts are key people associated with an account. A contact can only belong to one account, however, a contact may be associated with multiple opportunities. Your access to contact information is determined by your access rights to that contact's account. You always have access to your personal contacts.

Url.Title: Using the Contact List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Contact List View The List view displays all of the contacts that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: Using the Contact Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Contact Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Adding a Contact
Url.Abstract: Adding Contact and Account Information You can use the Contact/Account Information view to add a new contact and account or to add a new contact to an existing account.

Url.Title: Editing a Contact
Url.Abstract: Editing a Contact Use the Contact Detail view to edit contact information. To undo any changes, click Reset before clicking the Save button.

Url.Title: Deleting a Contact
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Contact When you delete a contact you also delete the contact's history, notes, and any open activities. You can also delete contacts by deleting the contact's account.

Url.Title: Moving a Contact
Url.Abstract: Moving a Contact You can move a contact to another account. This is useful if companies merge and a contact's account changes, or if a contact simply joins another company and wants to maintain a business relationship.You can also use this feature to move a contact that was incorrectly created under the wrong account.

Url.Title: What Are Accounts?
Url.Abstract: What Are Accounts? Accounts are your customers. Accounts can contain one or many contacts and are owned by an individual user, a team of users, or everyone. Access to accounts and account-related information depends on the account type and your access rights.

Url.Title: Using the Account List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Account List View The Account List view displays all of the accounts that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display..

Url.Title: Using the Account Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Account Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Adding a New Account
Url.Abstract: Adding a New Account You can use the Insert New Account dialog box to add a new account. Your security access determines what functions are available. Contact your administrator for any access rights changes. WebViewer users may not access full functionality.

Url.Title: Editing an Account
Url.Abstract: Editing an Account Use the Account Detail view to edit account information. To undo any changes, click Reset before clicking the Save button.

Url.Title: Deleting an Account
Url.Abstract: Deleting an Account When you delete an account, you also delete contact, account, and opportunity history, notes, and any open activities.

Url.Title: Linking Records with an Accounting System
Url.Abstract: Linking Records with an Accounting System This feature is only available if your administrator has configured Accounting Integration.

Url.Title: What Are Opportunities?
Url.Abstract: What Are Opportunities? Your potential sales to accounts and contacts are called opportunities. Opportunities allow you to collect and report on a variety of information relating to an opportunity, such as probability of closing a sale, estimated close dates, and more. You can track any combination of the following opportunity-related information.

Url.Title: Using the Opportunity List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Opportunity List View The List view displays all of the contacts that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: Using the Opportunity Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Opportunity Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Adding a New Opportunity
Url.Abstract: Adding a New Opportunity Use the Insert Opportunity view to enter opportunity information and to add, edit, or remove products, competitors, or contacts. You can also update the opportunity currency and rate if you have Multi-Currency enabled.

Url.Title: Editing an Opportunity
Url.Abstract: Editing an Opportunity Use the Opportunity Detail view to edit opportunity information. To undo any changes, click Reset before clicking the Save button.

Url.Title: Closing an Opportunity
Url.Abstract: Closing an Opportunity When you are ready to close an opportunity, you can change the status of the opportunity in the Opportunity Detail view to Closed-Won or Closed-Lost. It is recommended that you close an opportunity even if it is not a sale. For future reference and reporting purposes, you should provide the reason for closing the opportunity. Use the Opportunity Comments box to provide more information on the reason for the loss or for the won sale.

Url.Title: Deleting an Opportunity
Url.Abstract: Deleting an Opportunity To delete an opportunity On the Navigation Bar, click Opportunities. Opportunities

Url.Title: What are Sales Orders?
Url.Abstract: What Are Sales Orders? Sales Orders track the products purchased by your accounts. Sales orders include information such as, the date the sales order was made, the date the sales order was promised to the customer and its status.

Url.Title: Using the Sales Order List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Sales Order List View The Sales Orders List view displays all the sales orders that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: Using the Sales Order Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Sales Order Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Adding a Sales Order
Url.Abstract: Adding a Sales Order Use this view to add a sales order, including the billing address, shipping address or product information and other sales order information.

Url.Title: Editing a Sales Order
Url.Abstract: Editing a Sales Order Use the Sales Order Detail view to edit sales order information. To undo any changes, click Reset before clicking the Save button.

Url.Title: Copying a Sales Order
Url.Abstract: Copying a Sales Order You can copy sales order information such as, account, billing, shipping and product information.

Url.Title: Using Widgets
Url.Abstract: Using Widgets Sage SalesLogix provides several out-of-the-box widgets. You can add, edit, and remove widgets from the dashboard, and you can rearrange widgets on the page with drag-and-drop.

Url.Title: Introducing Dashboards
Url.Abstract: Introducing Dashboards The Dashboard allows you to display and interact with a variety of performance and analysis tools on the Welcome page of the Sage SalesLogix Web Client. You can maintain one or more personalized dashboard tabs and, with the appropriate permissions, you can modify dashboards provided by Sage or customized by your administrator.

Url.Title: Working with Dashboards
Url.Abstract: Working with Dashboards Dashboards display as tabs on the Welcome page and contain customizable, pre-defined analytics in the form of charting and list widgets. The Welcome page can contain multiple dashboard instances and each dashboard can contain multiple widgets.

Url.Title: Introducing Widgets
Url.Abstract: Introducing Widgets Widgets are plug-ins you can add to a dashboard. There are several types of widgets you can use to display your data. Move your mouse over the chart in a widget to display the dimension and metric selected for that widget.

Url.Title: Customer Service Overview
Url.Abstract: Customer Service Overview The Customer Service and Support features allow designated users to track, qualify, and resolve customer questions and issues. With these features, users can better analyze customer service issues to improve customer satisfaction.

Url.Title: What are Tickets?
Url.Abstract: What are Tickets? Tickets are records of customer inquiries or complaints. They can contain the information necessary to report, investigate, and close an inquiry or problem. You can insert new tickets for an account or contact, track your time spent resolving issues for a ticket against a contract by using the Punch In/Punch Out button record calendar and other activities for a ticket, and search for existing tickets using the Lookup. In addition, you can use SpeedSearch to search for existing problems and their resolutions that may apply to the ticket's issue.

Url.Title: Using the Ticket List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Ticket List View The List view displays all of the tickets that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: Adding a Ticket
Url.Abstract: Adding a New Ticket Use the Insert New Ticket view to add a new ticket for a new inquiry or problem for an account. Before you add a ticket, the account and contact must already exist in Sage SalesLogix.

Url.Title: Using the Ticket Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Ticket Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Editing or Closing a Ticket
Url.Abstract: Editing or Closing a Ticket When you need to change the status of a ticket, or make changes to a ticket's information, use the Ticket Detail view. To undo any changes, click Reset before clicking the Save button.

Url.Title: Deleting a Ticket
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Ticket Your security access determines what functions are available. Contact your administrator for any access rights changes. WebViewer users may not access full functionality.

Url.Title: What are Contracts?
Url.Abstract: What are Contracts? Contracts are agreements that detail specific support after the sale of a product. A Warranty, for example, can become a contract to support a specific asset after the sale.

Url.Title: Using the Contract List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Contract List View The Contract List view displays all of the contracts that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: Using the Contract Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Contract Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Adding a Contract
Url.Abstract: Adding a Contract Use the Insert New Contract view to create a contract record. Use the copy button to quickly create a new record with similar information.

Url.Title: Making a Contract Inactive
Url.Abstract: Making a Contract Inactive You can make a contract inactive when no tickets are associated with it. Inactive contracts will still appear in the Account Service Information dialog box.

Url.Title: Contract Types
Url.Abstract: Contract Types The five default contract types are: Type Description Days The contract is tracked according to a number of days of services the account has purchased. This value is entered into the Quantity box for the contract. When the contract type is Days, and as activities are generated for the account, the value in the Remaining box will not decrement.

Url.Title: What are Defects?
Url.Abstract: What are Defects? A defect is a record describing a problem in a product or process. It is similar to a ticket, but people involved in the design or construction of the product typically resolve defects. The system tracks defects so that problems with a product or process can be resolved in a timely manner, and company management is aware of issues with these products or processes.

Url.Title: Using the Defect List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Defect List View The Defect List view displays all of the defects that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: Using the Defect Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Defect Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Adding a Defect
Url.Abstract: Adding a Defect Use the Insert New Defect view to create a defect record. Use the copy button to quickly create a new record with similar information.

Url.Title: Closing a Defect
Url.Abstract: Closing a Defect The stage at which a defect is closed and the person responsible for closing the defect depend on the process within your company.

Url.Title: Working with Returns
Url.Abstract: Working with Returns Returns are agreements to accept returned products from a customer for service, replacement, refund, or credit You can use the Return Detail view to work with a single return, or the Returns List view to work with returns in a spreadsheet-type format.

Url.Title: Using the Return List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Return List View The Return List view displays all of the returns that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: Using the Return Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Return Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Adding a Return
Url.Abstract: Adding a Return Use the Insert Return view to create a return record. Your security access determines what functions are available. Contact your administrator for any access rights changes. WebViewer users may not access full functionality.

Url.Title: Closing a Return
Url.Abstract: Closing a Return The stage at which a return is closed and the person responsible for closing the return depend on the process within your company. As an example, when the product has been returned by the customer and the replacement product has been shipped, that might be the stage at which you would close a return.

Url.Title: What Are Assets?
Url.Abstract: What Are Assets? Assets are products that have been sold to your customers. They are the physical products the customer owns which may or may not be serialized.

Url.Title: Adding an Account Asset
Url.Abstract: Adding or Editing an Account Asset or Editing You can add a new asset to an account or edit the list of assets associated with an account.

Url.Title: What Are Activities and Events?
Url.Abstract: What Are Activities and Events? Activities include placing phone calls, attending meetings and completing to-dos such as sending correspondence or preparing presentations. Activities are generally scheduled for a specific time. Timeless activities are scheduled to occur on a selected day, but at no particular time. When you schedule an activity, it displays on the Calendar and Activities view, and in the Activities tabs on some detail views. Completed activities become history items.

Url.Title: Scheduling or Editing an Activity
Url.Abstract: Scheduling or Editing an Activity Use the Activity detail view to add or edit an activity or to see in-depth information about an activity, including date, time, duration, and notes. You can also complete or delete an activity after you schedule it.

Url.Title: Completing an Activity
Url.Abstract: Completing an Activity When you complete an activity, or write an e-mail, letter or fax, details about it are recorded in the Notes/History tab for the related account, contact, lead, ticket or opportunity.

Url.Title: Completing an Activity from the Menu
Url.Abstract: Completing an Activity from the Menu You may complete a regularly scheduled activity or create and then complete an unscheduled activity. An unscheduled activity is an activity that was not scheduled prior to completion.

Url.Title: Completing Multiple Activities
Url.Abstract: Completing Multiple Activities You can complete multiple activities from the Activities view. You can either complete multiple activities at the same time, or complete each activity separately. If you choose to complete each activity separately, the Complete Activity view will open allowing you to edit activity information before completing it. Once you complete an activity, the Complete Activity view will open for the next selected activity until each of the selected activities have been completed.

Url.Title: Deleting an Activity
Url.Abstract: Deleting an Activity You can delete any activity that you create. To delete a single activity Do one of the following:

Url.Title: Scheduling/Editing an Event
Url.Abstract: Scheduling or Editing an Event Events can be scheduled, edited, deleted, and viewed in the Web Client.

Url.Title: Calendar Options
Url.Abstract: Setting Calendar Options Use the Calendar tab to set the default options for your calendar. Calendar Options allow you to adjust the content and appearance of your calendar to accommodate the way you work. You can set the type of information that displays in activities, the start and end of the work day, the default calendar view, default interval on the calendar, and whether or not completed activities (history) items display. History items only display on the day and week calendars by default.

Url.Title: Activity Calendar
Url.Abstract: Using the Calendar Use the Calendar to manage your time and keep track of scheduled activities and events. The Sage SalesLogix Calendar displays both open and completed activities and events, depending on your calendar options. You can view your schedule by the day, week, or month view. Use the calendar right-click menu to schedule, edit, complete, or delete activities and events.

Url.Title: What Are Contact Processes?
Url.Abstract: What Are Contact Processes? A process is a series of tasks that are executed in a specific sequence over a period of time. Use Contact Processes to automate repetitive tasks and provide a consistent, automated way of following up with customers. Contact Processes are created using the Architect.

Url.Title: Process Manager
Url.Abstract: Using the Process Manager The Contact Process Manager on the Web allows you to view the processes assigned to your contacts or add new processes. Any further changes to processes must be done in the Sage SalesLogix Network Client or Sage SalesLogix Remote Client. Use the Processes tab in the Contact Detail view to view processes attached to a single contact.

Url.Title: Scheduling a Process
Url.Abstract: Scheduling a Process This feature is not available to WebViewer users. To schedule a process Do one of the following:

Url.Title: What are Sales Processes?
Url.Abstract: What are Sales Processes? This functionality is only available when the appropriate license is installed. For complete information about licensing, see the Sage SalesLogix Planning Guide.

Url.Title: Updating Sales Process Stages
Url.Abstract: Updating Sales Process Stages You can update the stages in a Sales Process. You can complete a stage even if you have not completed all of the stage steps. You can also change the current stage.

Url.Title: Finding Sales Processes
Url.Abstract: Finding Sales Processes Sales processes help you to manage your sales pipeline. You can attach a sales process to an open opportunity by selecting from a list of available processes.

Url.Title: What are Leads?
Url.Abstract: What are Leads? Leads are unqualified potential customers. Use lead qualification criteria to determine if a lead has valid information, already exists as a lead or contact, or is ready to be converted to a sales opportunity. Once qualified, a lead can be converted to or merged with a contact and account. You can also create a new sales opportunity.

Url.Title: Using the Lead List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Lead List View The Lead List view displays all the leads that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: Using the Lead Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Lead Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Adding a Lead
Url.Abstract: Adding a Lead Use the Insert Lead dialog box to add a new lead to the Sage SalesLogix Web Client. Sage SalesLogix Web Client

Url.Title: Importing Leads from a List
Url.Abstract: Importing Leads from a List Use the Import Leads view to import lists of leads into Sage SalesLogix. You may only import leads from a comma-separated-values (CSV) list. Valid file types include Microsoft Excel, .txt files, and other database file types, but files must be saved as a CSV file.

Url.Title: Qualifying Leads
Url.Abstract: Qualifying a Lead A lead may contain unqualified information. You can use lead qualification criteria to validate information and determine if the lead is a sales opportunity. Once qualified, you can convert a lead to a contact and account and create a new sales opportunity.

Url.Title: Deleting Leads
Url.Abstract: Deleting Leads Deleting a lead also deletes all information associated with the lead. To delete a lead

Url.Title: Adding a Campaign
Url.Abstract: Adding a Campaign Use the Insert Campaign view to add campaign information. After adding a campaign you can add products, stages and tasks, and targets.

Url.Title: Deleting a Campaign
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Campaign When you delete a campaign, you also delete all of the information associated with that campaign, including response and opportunity information.

Url.Title: Copying a Campaign
Launching a Campaign
Url.Abstract: Launching a Campaign When a campaign is launched, the campaign target contacts and leads are assigned to the first stage of a campaign and their status is changed to "Launched".

Url.Title: Using the Campaign Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Campaign Detail View Use the Detail view to see, add, or edit information for a selected record. The Detail view consists of information boxes, tabs, and a user-defined middle section.

Url.Title: Using the Campaign List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Campaign List View The List view displays all of the campaigns that you have access to. You can use groups and lookups to narrow the list of records that display.

Url.Title: What are Campaign Targets?
Url.Abstract: What are Campaign Targets? Targets are the contacts and leads that will be contacted as part of a campaign. You can segment the market in order to create a suitable list of campaign targets that fits within your budget.

Url.Title: Managing Campaign Targets
Url.Abstract: Managing Campaign Targets Use the Lookup Targets dialog box to determine which contacts and leads should be targeted for a campaign.

Url.Title: Campaign Stages and Tasks Tab
Url.Abstract: Campaign Stages/Tasks Tab The Campaign Stages/Tasks tab lists all of the stages and tasks associated with a campaign.

Url.Title: Adding/Editing/Completing Campaign Stages
Url.Abstract: Adding/Editing/Completing Campaign Stages Campaign stages are groups of tasks that can help Sage SalesLogix Marketing users manage their campaigns. You can add and edit stage information, or complete a stage once it is finished.

Url.Title: Adding/Editing/Completing Campaign Tasks
Url.Abstract: Adding/Editing/Completing Campaign Tasks Campaign tasks can help Sage SalesLogix Marketing users manage their campaigns. You can add and edit task information, or complete a task once it is finished.

Url.Title: Using Mail Merge
Url.Abstract: Using Mail Merge You can use Mail Merge when you need to correspond with a group of contacts, accounts, opportunities, or leads. Mail Merge helps you simplify the process of sending the same information to numerous people by merging information into a template. You can merge to a file, send an e-mail, send a fax, or print the merged document.

Url.Title: Templates Overview
Url.Abstract: Templates Overview You can use templates to create letters, proposals, faxes, or e-mail messages that will be used for more than one contact or lead. Templates use standard text that does not change, as well as mail merge fields that use Sage SalesLogix information that changes depending upon the contact or lead being merged.

Url.Title: About the Write Menu
Url.Abstract: Using the Write Menu You can use the Sage SalesLogix Write menu to perform a mail merge or to send an e-mail. You can communicate with a single contact or lead or with a group of contacts or leads.

Url.Title: Writing and Sending an E-mail Message
Url.Abstract: Writing and Sending an E-mail Message You can write an e-mail to a single contact or lead using either the Write E-mail or the Write E-mail Using Template option. If you need to send an e-mail message to more than one contact or lead, use Mail Merge.

Url.Title: Writing and Sending a Fax Message
Url.Abstract: Writing and Sending a Fax Message The following describes how to write and send a fax to a single contact or lead. If you need to send a fax to more than one contact or lead, use Mail Merge.

Url.Title: Writing and Sending Letters or Memos
Url.Abstract: Writing and Sending Letters or Memos The following describes how to write a letter to a single contact or lead. If you need to send a letter or memo to more than one contact or lead, use Mail Merge.

Url.Title: Printing Address Labels or Envelopes
Url.Abstract: Printing Address Labels or Envelopes You can use Mail Merge to create and print address labels and envelopes. You can create address labels or envelopes for one contact or lead or for multiple contacts or leads.

Url.Title: Viewing Invalid or Failed Merge Information
Url.Abstract: Viewing Invalid or Failed Merge Information Sage SalesLogix Mail Merge provides two forms of information when invalid or failed merges occur:

Url.Title: What are Reports?
Url.Abstract: What are Reports? The Reports view provides access to a set of pre-defined database queries that produce commonly used business reports. The specific reports available are determined by your system administrator, and are typically customized to the needs of your business.

Url.Title: Report Preview
Url.Abstract: Report Preview When you run a report, you can choose to preview it in the Sage SalesLogix Crystal Report Viewer before printing it. From the Viewer, you can print or export, adjust your on-screen view, and search for text in a report.

Url.Title: Running a Report
Url.Abstract: Running a Report Reports enable you to view information about contacts, accounts, opportunities, tickets, and other related data.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting Reports
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting Sage SalesLogix Web Reporting The following is a list of error messages most prevalent in Sage SalesLogix Web Reporting:

Url.Title: SpeedSearch
Url.Abstract: SpeedSearch SpeedSearch is a powerful tool that helps you find information stored in the Sage SalesLogix database or external files. For example, you can search through existing tickets or procedures to help solve a customer's problem, or search for a specific document, like a sales presentation. The type of information you can search for depends on the indexes your system administrator has set up in the Administrator.

Url.Title: Using SpeedSearch from the Menu Bar
Url.Abstract: Using SpeedSearch from the Menu Bar You can now enter your search criteria and perform a SpeedSearch from the Menu Bar.

Url.Title: Searching for Information
Url.Abstract: Searching for Information Use SpeedSearch to set up your search criteria and start a search. How you set up the search criteria determines how and where SpeedSearch locates items matching the keywords you enter.

Url.Title: What Are Groups?
Url.Abstract: What are Groups? Groups are a collection of records. Groups can help you manage your workflow. You can use groups to work with a subset of records, select data to print on reports, and to send mailings, e-mails, and faxes using the Mail Merge feature. A record can be in more than one group. You can export group records to Excel or share your groups with other users.

Url.Title: Saving a Lookup as a Group
Url.Abstract: Saving a Lookup as a Group After you create a lookup to find contacts, accounts, opportunities, leads or tickets, you may want to save the lookup as a group so you can access it again.

Url.Title: Adding an Ad Hoc Group
Url.Abstract: Adding an Ad Hoc Group You can create an ad hoc group to store a list of selected records from any of the List views.

Url.Title: Modifying Groups
Url.Abstract: Modifying Groups You can use Query Builder to modify your groups. To modify a group Open a list or detail view.

Url.Title: Sharing Templates with Other Users
Url.Abstract: Sharing Templates with Other Users You can share your templates with other Sage SalesLogix users, teams, or departments.

Url.Title: Exporting a Group to Excel
Url.Abstract: Exporting a Group to Excel You can export groups to Excel. The group column headings and formatting will also be exported.

Url.Title: Creating an Advanced Query
Url.Abstract: Adding an Advanced Query Group Use Query Builder to create a group. Advanced queries allow you to set the conditions for the group. Each time you open the group, the query evaluates the database to determine which records to display. If you want to ensure the group does not change, create an ad hoc group instead.

Url.Title: Using Query Builder
Url.Abstract: What is the Query Builder? Query Builder enables you to select data from the database based on one or more conditions. For example, you may need to see a list of primary contacts in the banking industry. Query Builder is connected to various areas throughout the Sage SalesLogix clients. To use Query Builder effectively, you must understand the Sage SalesLogix database structure and relational database concepts, such as data relationships and joins.

Url.Title: Opening Query Builder
Url.Abstract: Opening Query Builder You can use Query Builder to add or edit groups. add edit To open Query Builder Do one of the following:

Url.Title: View the SQL Version of a Query
Url.Abstract: Viewing the SQL Version of a Query When you create a query, it is converted to a SQL (Structured Query Language) statement. This statement is applied against the database. You can view the SQL version of a query, but you cannot modify the SQL statement.

Url.Title: Query Builder Properties
Url.Abstract: Query Builder Properties Use the Query Builder Properties tab to enter the name and purpose of a query.

Url.Title: Query Builder Conditions
Url.Abstract: Query Builder Conditions Use the Query Builder Conditions tab to add, edit, or delete conditional statements that are applied against the database to select data. Conditions are applied in the order they appear in the grid; however, you can use the Move Up and Move Down buttons to change the order. You can also group the conditional statements.

Url.Title: Query Builder Layout
Url.Abstract: Query Builder Layout Use the Query Builder Layout tab to specify which fields are displayed and how the data appears. You can add, edit, delete, or reorder the fields in the layout. You can also set the column name, width, and format of each field. The Layout tab must include at least one field or no data will appear.

Url.Title: Query Builder Sorting
Url.Abstract: Query Builder Sorting Use the Query Builder Sorting tab to specify which field(s) to sort the data by and whether the data appears in ascending or descending order. The sorting criteria are applied in the order in which they appear on the tab.

Url.Title: Query Builder Defaults
Url.Abstract: Query Builder Defaults Use the Query Builder Defaults tab to select only distinct records. distinct records

Url.Title: Joining Tables
Url.Abstract: Joining Tables The connection between two tables is called a join and is established using a field that exists in both tables. This field may have a different name in each table but contains the same information. There are two kinds of joins - Local and Global.

Url.Title: Guidelines for Using Joins
Url.Abstract: Guidelines for Using Joins Use the following guidelines when creating table joins in Sage SalesLogix:

Url.Title: Global Join Manager
Url.Abstract: Global Join Manager System Administrator Only Use extreme care when creating global joins, as it is possible to create a global join that can cause system performance problems.

Url.Title: Using Calculated Fields
Url.Abstract: Using Calculated Fields System Administrator Only A calculated field is dynamic and consists of two or more fields from the database. The fields used to create a calculated field can come from one table or from several joined tables. The values that appear for a calculated field are updated after changes are made to the fields comprising it. A calculated field can perform mathematical operations or concatenate strings, depending on the type of calculation.

Url.Title: Adding or Editing a Calculated Field
Url.Abstract: Adding and Editing Calculated Fields System Administrator Only To open the Manage Calculated Fields dialog box

Url.Title: Delete a Calculated Field
Url.Abstract: Deleting Calculated Fields System Administrator Only You can only open the Manage Calculated Fields dialog box if you are logged on as an administrator.

Url.Title: Intellisync for SalesLogix
Url.Abstract: Intellisync for SalesLogix Intellisync for SalesLogix is a separate program installed and integrated with Sage SalesLogix. Intellisync for SalesLogix enables you to share your Sage SalesLogix activities and contacts with Microsoft Outlook and Lotus Notes.

Url.Title: Configuring Intellisync for SalesLogix
Url.Abstract: Configuring Intellisync for SalesLogix Synchronization preferences must be configured on each user’s computer. To sync, an ad hoc group must exist in Sage SalesLogix, and be configured as the sync group. To configure Intellisync, you will need the URL for the Intellisync for SalesLogix portal. Contact your system administrator for more information.

Url.Title: Using Intellisync
Url.Abstract: Using Intellisync For SalesLogix After configuration, Intellisync for SalesLogix will synchronize files between Sage SalesLogix and Microsoft Outlook or Lotus Notes on the schedule you specified during configuration. Occasionally, it may be necessary to:

Url.Title: Administering Intellisync for SalesLogix
Url.Abstract: Administering Intellisync for SalesLogix This topic contains information for administrators and administrative users who are tasked with troubleshooting Intellisync for SalesLogix.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting Common Issues The following are commonly experienced issues: Problem: My queries all return the same data and I keep getting the same pages.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting Desktop Integration - Mail Merge
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting Desktop Integration - Mail Merge You may encounter the following issues with Desktop Integration and Mail Merge.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting Desktop Integration - Send SLX and Record to History
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting Desktop Integration - Send SLX and Record to History You may encounter the following issues with Desktop Integration and Send SLX.

Url.Title: I Do Not See Updated Data
Url.Abstract: I Do Not See Updated Data Problem: My list view is not updated after importing, deleting or updating multiple records.

Url.Title: Glossary of Terms
Url.Abstract: Glossary of Terms Access Rights A user's ability to access data and use Sage SalesLogix Network Client features. The system administrator creates a security profile for each user in Sage SalesLogix Administrator, which determines each user's access rights within the Sage SalesLogix Client.

Url.Title: Using the Account Assets Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Account Assets Tab Using the Use this tab to view a list of assets associated with won opportunities or added to an account.

Url.Title: Account Details Tab
Url.Abstract: Account Details Tab The Details tab appears in the Account Detail view. This tab contains specific information about the account. You can edit the information at any time by clicking in a box and typing new information, or select from a list of available items.

Url.Title: Account Detail View Contacts Tab
Url.Abstract: Account Detail View Contacts Tab You can use the Contacts tab to display the list of contacts associated with the current account. You can also add contacts to an account using the Contacts tab.

Url.Title: Account Detail View Contracts Tab
Url.Abstract: Account Detail View Contracts Tab The Contracts tab on the Account Detail view allows you to see specific contract information for the account in one location. You can use this tab to verify contract information rather than opening each contract separately.

Url.Title: Account Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Account Information Boxes The account information boxes contain information about the selected account. You can edit or delete the information as needed.

Url.Title: Associating Accounts
Url.Abstract: Account Association Detail View Use associations to create a relationship between accounts. For example, if you were working with a company with multiple divisions, you could create an account for each division (divisional accounts), and create an account to represent the company as a whole (parent account). You could then associate each divisional account with the parent account. If there were contacts in different divisions of the parent company, you could then associate the contacts.

Url.Title: New Account Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Account Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description Account

Url.Title: Opportunities Tab - Account Detail view
Url.Abstract: Opportunities Tab - Account Detail view You can view information about the opportunities linked to the selected account. You can also create a new opportunity for the account.

Url.Title: Reseller Opportunities Tab
Url.Abstract: Reseller Opportunities Tab You can use the Reseller Opportunities tab on the Account Detail view to view opportunity information for resellers. The Reseller Opportunities tab displays a list of the opportunities that the account is a reseller for.

Url.Title: Activities Tab
Url.Abstract: Activities Tab The Activities tab appears in the Account, Contact, Ticket, Lead, and Opportunity Detail views. Use the Activities tab to manage activities and events related to the current record. Information displayed on the Activities tab includes the activity type, date and time, duration, user, category and regarding.

Url.Title: Working with the Activities List View Shortcut Menu
Url.Abstract: Working with the Activities List View Shortcut Menu The Activities List view shortcut menu enables you to view, complete or delete the activity, or open the associated contact or lead.

Url.Title: Adding and Removing Activity Resources
Url.Abstract: Availability Tab The Availability tab shows you when the leader, other Sage SalesLogix activity members, or any required resources are free or busy to help you schedule your activity. You can only manage members or resources required for a phone call or meeting.

Url.Title: Setting Reminders
Url.Abstract: Setting Alarms Alarms can alert you to an activity that is due to be completed. You can set an alarm for an existing activity or when you schedule an activity. You must have Alerts set up to include alarms in order to be notified of your alarms.

Url.Title: Alarms Tab
Url.Abstract: Alarms Tab The Alarms tab in the Activities view lists activities with active alarms. From this tab you can view and then snooze or dismiss your alarms.

Url.Title: Using Alerts
Url.Abstract: Using Alerts Alerts help you keep track of activities with triggered alarms and unconfirmed activities. Your Alerts options determine how you will be alerted for alarms and new unconfirmed activities.

Url.Title: All Open Tab
Url.Abstract: All Open Tab The All Open tab in the Activities view displays all open (not completed) activities such as phone calls, meetings, to-dos and personal activities scheduled for the selected user or users.

Url.Title: Working with Calendar Shortcut Menus
Url.Abstract: Working with Calendar Shortcut Menus Calendar shortcut menus enable you to schedule a new activity, or to work with scheduled activities. The shortcut menu options available vary depending on where the menu is accessed.

Url.Title: What are Activity Confirmations?
Url.Abstract: Activity Confirmations Activity confirmations notify you of activities where you are a member or the leader. You are notified when another user adds you as a member or leader to an activity or when an activity that you are a member of is updated or deleted. If you are added as a member, you must confirm or decline the activity. If you schedule an activity with other members, you receive a notification when a member confirms or declines the activity.

Url.Title: Confirmations Tab
Url.Abstract: Confirmations Tab The Confirmations tab on the Activities view displays meetings or phone calls that other users have invited you to attend and enables you to accept or decline these activities. If the activity leader changes the activity's date, time, or duration, you will need to confirm or decline the changed activity.

Url.Title: Recurring Activities, Daily
Url.Abstract: Recurring Activities, Daily You can choose to schedule an activity to occur once, daily, weekly, monthly or yearly.

Url.Title: Deleting an Event
Url.Abstract: Deleting an Event You can delete any event you create from the Activity List view. To delete an event Open the Activities List view.

Url.Title: Events Tab
Url.Abstract: Events Tab Use the Events tab on the Activities view to view and filter your scheduled events. How Do I?

Url.Title: Literature Tab
Url.Abstract: Literature Tab The Literature tab in the Activities view lists literature requests scheduled by a selected user or users. Literature can include catalogues, brochures, advertisements, and so on.

Url.Title: Recurring Activities, Monthly
Url.Abstract: Recurring Activities, Monthly You can choose to schedule an activity to occur once, daily, weekly, monthly or yearly.

Url.Title: My Activities Tab
Url.Abstract: My Activities Tab The My Activities tab in the Activities view displays all of the activities in which you are a leader or member. If an activity is recurring, only the first or current occurrence displays.

Url.Title: Recurring Activities, Once
Url.Abstract: Recurring Activities, Once You can choose to schedule an activity to occur once, daily, weekly, monthly or yearly.

Url.Title: Past Due Tab
Url.Abstract: Past Due Tab The Past Due tab in the Activities view displays all of your past due activities. An activity is considered past due when the scheduled start time has expired and the activity does not have an alarm.

Url.Title: Recurring Activities
Url.Abstract: Scheduling a Recurring Activity Recurring activities take place at the same time each day, week, month, or year. Examples are a staff meeting every Monday at 10 AM, or a board meeting at 9 PM on the second Monday of each month.

Url.Title: Setting Activities Options
Url.Abstract: Setting Activities Options Use the Activities tab to set defaults such as activity type. To set activity options

Url.Title: Using the Timezone Calculator
Url.Abstract: Using the Time Zone Calculator The Time Zone Calculator allows you to schedule an activity based on the time zones of the participants. For example, you may have scheduled a phone call with a customer for 10:00 AM your time and want to determine the time for your customer in a different time zone.

Url.Title: Recurring Activities, Weekly
Url.Abstract: Recurring Activities, Weekly You can choose to schedule an activity to occur once, daily, weekly, monthly or yearly.

Url.Title: Working with the Activities View
Url.Abstract: Working with the Activities View Use the Activities view to manage your scheduled activities, events, literature requests, and confirmations. If you have additional access rights, you can also view other Sage SalesLogix users' activities. Use the Summary view or Details pane to see additional information for each activity. You can use filters to narrow the list of records in the list. For example, if the time frame is next month, use the Time Frame filter to show only activities scheduled for next month.

Url.Title: Recurring Activities, Yearly
Url.Abstract: Recurring Activities, Yearly You can choose to schedule an activity to occur once, daily, weekly, monthly or yearly.

Url.Title: Assigning Users to the Standard User Role
Url.Abstract: Assigning Users to the Standard User Role By default, users created in the Web Client are assigned the Standard User role. This role allows add, edit, and delete permissions to Web Client non-administrative entities such as accounts, contacts, and opportunities.

Url.Title: Creating a Secured Action
Url.Abstract: Creating a Secured Action The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.The system administrator and users with an administrator role can access these features.

Url.Title: Editing or Deleting a Secured Action
Url.Abstract: Editing or Deleting a Secured Action The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.The system administrator and users with an administrator role can access these features.

Url.Title: Editing or Deleting a Role
Url.Abstract: Editing or Deleting a Role The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using the Roles List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Roles List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Actions Tab
Url.Abstract: Actions Tab Use the Actions tab in the Role Detail view to manage the secured actions assigned to a role. A role determines what functionality a user can access in the Web Client. Adding secured actions to a role determines what functionality the role gives access to. Adding users to the role determines who gets the access.

Url.Title: Role Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Role Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Users Tab
Url.Abstract: Users Tab Use the Users tab to assign one or more users to a role or to remove a user from a role. When a user is assigned to a role, the user has access to the actions defined in that role. If a user is assigned to more than one role, he/she will have access to all secured actions within the roles even if each role does not contain the same actions.

Url.Title: Using the Secured Action Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Secured Action Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.The system administrator and users with an administrator role can access these features.

Url.Title: Locations Tab
Url.Abstract: Locations Tab The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.The system administrator and users with an administrator role can access these features.

Url.Title: Roles Tab
Url.Abstract: Roles Tab The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.The system administrator and users with an administrator role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using the Secured Actions List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Secured Actions List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.The system administrator and users with an administrator role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using the Security Manager View
Url.Abstract: Using the Security Manager View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Adding or Editing a Security Profile
Url.Abstract: Adding or Editing a Security Profile The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Select a Role
Url.Abstract: Select a Role Use the Select Role dialog box to search for the role that you want to assign to the selected user(s) or secured action(s). Use the lookup to search for available roles.

Url.Title: Changing a Team's Owner
Url.Abstract: Changing a Team's Owner You can use the Teams view or Users view to change a team's owner. Teams may have multiple team owners.

Url.Title: Changing Department Members
Url.Abstract: Changing Department Members To modify department members, you can edit the department or change a user's profile.

Url.Title: Copying a Department
Url.Abstract: Copying a Department When you copy an existing department, all members are included in the new department.

Url.Title: Copying a Team
Url.Abstract: Copying a Team When you copy an existing team, all members are included in the new team. To copy Open the Team Detail view for the team you want to copy.

Url.Title: Deleting a Department
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Department The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Deleting or Renaming a Team
Url.Abstract: Deleting or Renaming a Team Use the Team Detail view to delete or rename a team. How Do I? Delete a Team

Url.Title: Using the Departments List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Departments List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Department Detail View
Url.Abstract: Department Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Department Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Department Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Members Tab
Url.Abstract: Members Tab The Members tab displays the users within a department. Use this tab to manage department members.

Url.Title: Teams Tab
Url.Abstract: Teams Tab The Teams tab displays the teams of which the department is a member. Use this tab to add or remove a department from a team.

Url.Title: Editing a Security Profile Within a Team
Url.Abstract: Editing a Security Profile Within a Team After you add a team member, you can modify the security rights. The initial security rights are set to match the user's default security profile. You cannot edit WebViewer security profiles. Tell me more about security...

Url.Title: Account Access Tab
Url.Abstract: Account Access Tab Use the Account Access tab to view all accounts owned by the selected team. Team members have access to the teams listed on this tab.

Url.Title: Using the Teams List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Teams List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Members Tab
Url.Abstract: Members Tab The Members tab displays the users, departments, and teams within a team. Use this tab to manage team members.

Url.Title: Team Detail View
Url.Abstract: Team Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Understanding Team Hierarchy
Url.Abstract: Understanding Team Hierarchy A team can consist of users, teams, and departments. When you add a user to a team, the user's immediate manager can also be included. However, there is no further inheritance (for example, the manager's manager). If you do not want the user's manager added to the team, you can clear this option on the Team Members tab.

Url.Title: Team Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Team Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Team Owner Profile
Url.Abstract: Team Owner Profile The Team Owner Profile is the only security profile that can change ownership. Any number of team members can be team owners.

Url.Title: Changing a User Type
Url.Abstract: Changing a User Type Use the User Detail view to convert a user from one type to another. For example, you can change a Web Only user to a Concurrent user. You may also want to retire a user or re-activate a Retired user.

Url.Title: Copying Profile Information
Url.Abstract: Copying Profile Information You can copy configuration information from an existing user or template to one or more users. Copying profile information from one user to another overwrites existing settings. Tell me more...

Url.Title: Creating a Copy of a User
Url.Abstract: Creating a Copy of a User When you create a copy of an existing user everything is copied except user specific information such as the user name, e-mail address, and other personal information.

Url.Title: Creating a User Template
Url.Abstract: Creating a User Template User templates define the settings you want to use when creating new users. Templates are recommended because they significantly reduce administration time.

Url.Title: Managing Calendar Access Rights
Url.Abstract: Managing Calendar Access Rights Set calendar access using the following options: Add Activities - allows a user to schedule an activity for another user.

Url.Title: Resetting Locked Out Users
Url.Abstract: Resetting Locked Out Users The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Understanding Field Level Security Precedence
Url.Abstract: Understanding Field Level Security Precedence When using field level security in the Web Client, greater access takes precedence over lesser access. Access is determined by combining the maximum access of all profiles assigned to that user and owner.

Url.Title: User Profile Client System Tab
Url.Abstract: Client System Tab Use the Client System tab on the User Detail view to define a user's base templates and to set the default owner of accounts created by this user. Users can change these settings on the General tab in Options.

Url.Title: Department Membership Tab
Url.Abstract: Department Membership Tab Use the Department Membership tab on the User Detail view to add or remove the user from departments. Users can belong to more than one department.

Url.Title: User Profile Employee Tab
Url.Abstract: Employee Tab Use the Employee tab on the User Detail view to add company and personal information for a user. The Employee tab also contains user-level information that allows Sage SalesLogix to communicate with supported third-party accounting applications.

Url.Title: User Profile Function Security Tab
Url.Abstract: Notes Tab Use the Notes tab on the User Detail view to add notes about the user. This tab allows you to add information that may not be captured on another tab.

Url.Title: Roles Tab
Url.Abstract: Roles Tab Use the Roles tab on the User Detail view to assign or remove a user from a role. When a user is assigned to a role, the user has access to the actions defined in that role. If a user is assigned to more than one role, he/she will have access to all secured actions within the roles even if each role does not contain the same actions.

Url.Title: User Profile Security Tab
Url.Abstract: Security Tab This functionality is only available when the appropriate license is installed. For complete information about licensing, see the Sage SalesLogix Planning Guide.

Url.Title: User Profile Service/Support Tab
Url.Abstract: Service/Support Tab Use the Service/Support tab on the User Detail view to set options related to customer service features, support features, and SpeedSearch. Consider the following when setting user access:

Url.Title: User Profile Teams Tab
Url.Abstract: Team Membership Tab This functionality is only available when the appropriate license is installed. For complete information about licensing, see the Sage SalesLogix Planning Guide.

Url.Title: User Profile Calendar Tab
Url.Abstract: User's Calendar Tab Use the User's Calendar tab on the User Detail view to set access rights for other users to view and modify this user’s calendar. By default, users do not have access to any other user’s calendars. When a user's calendar is added to another user's profile, view access rights are automatically enabled.

Url.Title: User Team Membership Tab
Url.Abstract: User Team Membership Tab User teams allow users to access accounts owned by another user. For example, if you want Lee to have access to all of Dan’s accounts, you can add Lee to Dan’s user team.

Url.Title: User Team Members Tab
Url.Abstract: User Team Members Tab User teams allow users to access accounts owned by another user. For example, if you want Lee to have access to all of Dan’s accounts, you can add Lee to Dan’s user team.

Url.Title: User Profile General Tab
Url.Abstract: User Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Asset Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Asset Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Deleting an Account Asset
Url.Abstract: Deleting an Account Asset If you have the appropriate permissions, you can delete an asset. To delete On the Account Detail view, select the Assets tab.

Url.Title: Adding Lead Sources to a Campaign
Url.Abstract: Adding Lead Sources to a Campaign You can add lead sources to a campaign using the Add Campaign Lead Source dialog box. Use the filter to narrow the list of lead sources in the Available Lead Sources tree view. You add lead sources by selecting them from the Available Lead Sources tree view and adding them to the Selected Lead Source grid. If you add a lead source in error, you can remove it.

Url.Title: Campaign Budget/Results Tab
Url.Abstract: Campaign Budget/Results Tab The Campaign Budget/Results tab helps you track campaign related costs. You can view the budget, response information, cost metrics, and opportunity statistics for the campaign. If Multi-Currency is configured, select the Display using "My Currency" check box to view budget and results information using the currency type you selected in your user options.

Url.Title: Deleting Campaign Stages
Url.Abstract: Deleting Campaign Stages Deleting a stage also deletes any tasks for that stage. To delete From the Campaign Detail view, select the Stages/Tasks tab, select the stage you want to delete, and then click Delete Stage.

Url.Title: Deleting Campaign Tasks
Url.Abstract: Deleting Campaign Tasks You can delete tasks from a campaign stage. To delete From the Campaign Detail view, select the Stages/Tasks tab,select the task you want to delete, and then click Delete Task.

Url.Title: Filtering Targets
Url.Abstract: Filtering Targets Use Include filter options to limit the target contacts and leads that display in the list. You can apply a filter by selecting the check box. The filters will retain your last selection(s) as the default values.

Url.Title: Campaign Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Campaign Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: What are Campaigns?
Url.Abstract: What are Campaigns? A campaign is a combination of various advertising, public relations, sales promotion, and selling activities used over a period of time to achieve predetermined sales or marketing goals. A campaign can target a specific industry or group. Sage SalesLogix Marketing allows you to track information such as the time frame of the campaign, products associated with the campaign, response rates for a campaign, and more.

Url.Title: Campaign Products Tab
Url.Abstract: Campaign Products Tab The Campaign Products tab lists all of the products associated with a campaign. You can add and remove campaign products.

Url.Title: Removing a Contact or Lead from a Campaign
Url.Abstract: Removing a Contact or Lead from a Campaign If a contact or lead does not want to be included in future campaign stages, you can remove the contact or lead from the campaign. The contact or lead is still listed as a campaign target, but the status is changed to Removed.

Url.Title: Campaign Responses Tab
Url.Abstract: Campaign Responses Tab The Campaign Responses tab lists all of the target responses for a campaign. You can add, edit, and delete campaign responses, as well as filter the list of responses.

Url.Title: Campaign Target and Response Filters
Url.Abstract: Campaign Target and Response Filters Use the Show Filters options to limit the target contacts and leads that display in the list.

Url.Title: Creating Campaign Target Groups
Url.Abstract: Creating Campaign Target Groups To manage your campaigns and campaign targets, you can create campaign target groups.

Url.Title: Campaign Targets Tab
Url.Abstract: Campaign Targets Tab The Campaign Targets tab lists all of the targets for a campaign. You can perform campaign related tasks such as, managing the target list, updating target information, exporting targets to Excel or creating a group. These features are not available if you use an external list of targets, but you can include information about the external list.

Url.Title: Updating Target Information
Url.Abstract: Updating Target Information Update multiple target contacts or leads at once using the Update Target dialog box. Use the boxes at the bottom of the dialog box to update multiple targets with the same information.

Url.Title: Campaign Opportunities Tab
Url.Abstract: Campaign Opportunities Tab The Campaign Opportunities tab lists all of the opportunities associated with a campaign.

Url.Title: Marketing Tab
Url.Abstract: Marketing Tab Use the Marketing tab on the Account, Contact or Lead Detail Views, to see the campaigns that targeted a contact or lead. You can also add or edit campaign response information, or remove a contact or lead from future stages of the campaign.

Url.Title: Setting Alerts Options
Url.Abstract: Setting Alerts Options Use the Alerts tab to set defaults to determine how you will be alerted for alarms and new unconfirmed activities.

Url.Title: Changing a Password
Url.Abstract: Changing a Password You can change your password through the Options in the Sage SalesLogix Web Client.

Url.Title: Selecting a Time Zone
Url.Abstract: Selecting a Time Zone The Sage SalesLogix Web Client displays your time zone in the status bar at the bottom of your browser window. The default time zone is based on your local machine's Time Zone setting. If the time zone is incorrect, you can change to another locale within the same time zone.

Url.Title: Recently Viewed
Url.Abstract: Recently Viewed Use the Recently Viewed features on the Menu Bar and Personal Workspace Welcome Tab to view a list of the records you have recently worked on.

Url.Title: Adding an Attachment
Url.Abstract: Adding an Attachment You can add an attachment to a record. All files are stored in the shared attachments directory and synchronize to and from remote databases.

Url.Title: Adding/Editing an Alternate Address
Url.Abstract: Adding/Editing an Alternate Address You can use the Address dialog box to change address information. You can have as many custom addresses as necessary for a contact or an account. However, you may select only one primary billing address and only one primary shipping address.

Url.Title: Addresses Tab
Url.Abstract: Addresses Tab The Addresses tab is located in the Account and Contact Detail views. This tab displays all addresses for the selected contact or account. Only the primary address is displayed in the Detail view.

Url.Title: Adding/Editing Response Information
Url.Abstract: Adding or Editing Response Information Use this dialog box to update response information. Responses keep track of interactions with a contact or lead. The response will appear in the Responses tabs for the Detail views.

Url.Title: Associations Tab
Url.Abstract: Associations Tab The Associations tab appears in both the Account and Contact Detail views. Associated contacts and accounts have a relationship with the selected contact or account.

Url.Title: Attachments Tab
Url.Abstract: Attachments Tab Attachments are files that are linked to a record. The Attachments tab is found on many of the detail views, including the Activity Detail view, and displays a list of attachments for the selected record.

Url.Title: Deleting an Attachment
Url.Abstract: Deleting an Attachment You can delete an attachment from a record. If you delete an attachment from a single occurrence of a recurring activity, the attachment is deleted from the entire series.

Url.Title: Deleting a Response
Url.Abstract: Removing a Response Remove a response if it was entered in error or no longer applies. You can also remove a campaign response from further stages of a campaign.

Url.Title: Deleting an Alternate Address
Url.Abstract: Deleting an Alternate Address You can delete an address that is no longer valid, as long as the address is not a shipping or primary address.

Url.Title: Dragging and Dropping
Url.Abstract: Dragging and Dropping Use the drag and drop feature to rearrange portions of the Sage SalesLogix interface. If you have installed Desktop Integration, you can also add attachments or Microsoft Outlook e-mail messages to Sage SalesLogix.

Url.Title: Editing Attachment Information
Url.Abstract: Editing Attachment Information Use this view to alter the attachment description and upload a new version of an attachment. Attachments synchronize.

Url.Title: Adding a History Item
Url.Abstract: Adding a History Item History items are completed activities, e-mails, questions, and database changes.

Url.Title: Deleting a History Item
Url.Abstract: Deleting a History Item You can only delete a history item that you create. To delete Open the Contact, Account, Lead or Opportunity Detail view with the associated history item, and then click the Notes/History tab. If the tab is not visible, click the More Tabs tab.

Url.Title: Viewing and Editing History Items and Notes
Url.Abstract: Viewing and Editing History Items and Notes Use the History Detail View to see in-depth information about a completed activity, e-mail, literature request, note, change to the database, Visual Basic script, or question.

Url.Title: Viewing a Map for an Address
Url.Abstract: Viewing a Map for an Address This function is only available for the first line of the primary address of an account, contact or lead. The second address line is not used. If the pound (#) sign appears in an address, place it on the second address line to allow MapQuest to better locate the address.

Url.Title: More Tabs
Url.Abstract: More Tabs Use More Tabs to open additional tab views. More Tabs may display on any of the Detail views. You can drag and drop tabs to and from the More Tabs section.

Url.Title: Adding a Note
Url.Abstract: Adding a Note You use notes to document the outcome of an activity and to record interactions with an account, contact, lead, or opportunity. The notes you add appear in the Notes/History tab on the Account, Contact, Lead, and Opportunity Detail views.

Url.Title: Deleting a Note
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Note You can only delete notes that you create. You must delete the entire history item associated with the note.

Url.Title: Notes/History Tab
Url.Abstract: Notes/History Tab The Notes/History Tab displays on the Account, Contact, Opportunity and Lead Detail views. The tab contains filtering options that allow you to quickly access important information. You can also use this tab to e-mail a history record, create a Microsoft Word document, view an attachment, or edit notes.

Url.Title: Campaign Responses Tab
Url.Abstract: Responses Tab Use the Responses tab on the Account, Contact or Lead Detail Views to see contact and lead responses. Responses keep track of interactions with a contact or lead. You can also add or edit response information.

Url.Title: Using the Returns Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Returns Tab The Returns tab on the Account and Ticket Detail views lists all returns for the selected record.

Url.Title: Tickets Tab
Url.Abstract: Tickets Tab The Tickets tab on the Contact and Account Detail views lists all tickets reported by the contact or account. You can use the Tickets tab to open the detail view of a selected ticket, or to add a new ticket.

Url.Title: Timeline
Url.Abstract: Timeline A Timeline shows the occurrence and duration of events, such as activities, history, tickets and opportunities over a period of time (past, present, and future).

Url.Title: Changing the Status of a Contact Process
Url.Abstract: Changing the Status of a Contact Process The Web Client allows you to suspend or abort a process, and to restart a suspended process. Aborted processes are permanently ended.

Url.Title: Lead Source Detail View
