Url.Title: Adding/Editing Opportunity Products
Url.Abstract: Adding Products to an Opportunity You can add opportunity products when you create an opportunity or from the Opportunity Detail view Products tab using the Lookup Product dialog box.

Url.Title: Editing Opportunity Product Information
Url.Abstract: Editing Opportunity Product Information Use this dialog box to enter product information such as quantity, price, or discount.

Url.Title: Opportunity Competitors
Url.Abstract: Opportunity Competitors Use this view to add, edit, or remove competitors associated with an opportunity and to help you plan your strategy.

Url.Title: Copying an Opportunity
Url.Abstract: Copying an Opportunity You can copy an existing opportunity to quickly create a new opportunity with the same competitors, contacts, and products as well as other information.

Url.Title: Removing Competitors from an Opportunity
Url.Abstract: Removing a Competitor from an Opportunity You can remove a competitor from an opportunity if that company is no longer competing for the sale, or was selected by mistake. You can delete competitors from the Insert Opportunity dialog box, or the Opportunity Detail view. Deleting a competitor only changes the competitor's association with a particular opportunity. The competitor is not deleted from the database.

Url.Title: Removing Contacts from an Opportunity
Url.Abstract: Removing a Contact from an Opportunity You can remove contacts from an opportunity at any time. You can remove contacts from the Insert Opportunity dialog box or the Opportunity Detail view. Deleting a contact only removes the contact's association with a particular opportunity. The contact is not deleted from the database.

Url.Title: Removing a Product from an Opportunity
Url.Abstract: Removing a Product from an Opportunity You can remove products from an opportunity if a customer is no longer interested in the product, or the products were added by mistake. You can remove products from the Insert Opportunity dialog box or Opportunity Detail view. Removing a product only removes the product's association with a particular opportunity. The product is not deleted from the database.

Url.Title: Editing the Sales Potential
Url.Abstract: Editing the Sales Potential The sales potential is the total revenue to be gained by the opportunity. By default, the sales potential is the calculated sum of all of the associated products.

Url.Title: Understanding Multi-Currency
Url.Abstract: Understanding Multi-Currency If your company has Sage SalesLogix users (or prospects) in multiple countries using different currencies, your system administrator can enable multi-currency support. If Multi-Currency is enabled, some Sage SalesLogix views will display information or options specific to your selected currency rate. For example, if you are using the British Pound as your default currency, opportunities will display pricing in pounds.

Url.Title: Updating Opportunity Currency
Url.Abstract: Updating the Opportunity Currency This functionality is only available if Multi-Currency is configured.

Url.Title: Editing Opportunity Competitors
Url.Abstract: Editing an Opportunity Competitor After you have added a competitor to an Opportunity, you can edit the competitor information from the Edit Competitor dialog box.

Url.Title: Editing Opportunity Contacts
Url.Abstract: Editing an Opportunity Contact After you have added a contact to an opportunity, you can edit the contact by adding information where needed. You cannot, however, change the contact or the contact's title.

Url.Title: Updating Multiple Opportunities
Url.Abstract: Updating Multiple Opportunities You can update multiple opportunities at once using the Update Opportunities dialog box.

Url.Title: Opportunity Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Opportunity Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Opportunity Marketing Tab
Url.Abstract: Opportunity Marketing Tab Use the Marketing tab on the Opportunity Detail view to see or add campaigns that are associated with the opportunity.

Url.Title: Opportunity Contacts
Url.Abstract: Opportunity Contacts Use this view to add, edit, or remove contacts associated to an opportunity. How Do I?

Url.Title: Opportunity Snapshot
Url.Abstract: Opportunity Snapshot You can view opportunity value and summary information about the selected opportunity in the Opportunity Snapshot in the top section of the Opportunity Detail view. You can edit the information as needed.

Url.Title: Opportunity Statistics
Url.Abstract: Using Opportunity Statistics You can use Opportunity Statistics to view opportunity information at a glance. You can view opportunity statistics for a group of opportunities, or you can select individual opportunities from the Opportunity List view. You can also export opportunities to Excel or view opportunity reports.

Url.Title: Summary Tab
Url.Abstract: Summary Tab The Opportunity Summary tab appears on the Opportunity Detail view and displays a list of activities and interactions with the selected opportunity. The Last rows relate to the last activity performed. The Next rows display scheduled follow up activities.

Url.Title: Setting Opportunity Options
Url.Abstract: Setting Opportunity Options Use the Opportunities tab to specify default settings for any new opportunities that you enter into the Sage SalesLogix Web Client. These options only apply when the current user is logged in to the Sage SalesLogix Web Client.

Url.Title: Opportunity Products
Url.Abstract: Opportunity Products Use this view to add, edit, or remove products associated with the opportunity. You can also change the product list order.

Url.Title: Setting Desktop Manager E-mail History Options
Url.Abstract: Setting Desktop Manager E-mail History Options Use the Sage SalesLogix Desktop Manager to enter connection information and set e-mail history options.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting Desktop Integration Module
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting Desktop Integration Module You may encounter the following issues with the Desktop Integration module.

Url.Title: Duplicate Record(s) Found
Url.Abstract: Duplicate Record(s) Found The Duplicate Record(s) Found view appears when you are recording an e-mail message from Outlook to Sage SalesLogix history, and more than one contact or lead has the same e-mail address. The DuplicateRecord(s) Found view shows the name, account or company name and e-mail address.

Url.Title: Completing an E-mail
Url.Abstract: Completing an E-mail Use the Complete - E-mail dialog box to record information about a completed e-mail.

Url.Title: Logging E-mail Message to History
Url.Abstract: Recording an E-mail Message to History If you are using Microsoft Outlook as your e-mail application, you can log messages you receive to the History tab in the Sage SalesLogix Web Client.

Url.Title: Completing Multiple E-mail History Records
Url.Abstract: Completing Multiple E-mail History Records The Quick Complete dialog box opens when you select multiple e-mails to log to history at once. Use the Quick Complete dialog box to enter history information for multiple e-mail messages or you can choose to log information for each e-mail individually.

Url.Title: Record(s) Not Found
Url.Abstract: Record(s) Not Found The Record(s) Not Found view appears when you are recording an e-mail message from Outlook to Sage SalesLogix history, and the contact or lead e-mail address is not in the Sage SalesLogix database. The Record(s) Not Found view shows the subject, who the e-mail is from, and to whom the e-mail is being sent.

Url.Title: Selecting Record(s) to Log History Items for
Url.Abstract: Selecting Record(s) to Log History Items for If you are using Microsoft Outlook as your e-mail application, you can save Outlook e-mail messages as Sage SalesLogix history items. If you send an e-mail to multiple contacts or leads, you can choose which records should receive the associated history item.

Url.Title: Using Outlook Integration
Url.Abstract: Using Outlook Integration You can use Outlook Integration to save Outlook e-mail messages as Sage SalesLogix history items. For example, you can:

Url.Title: Qualification Items Tab
Url.Abstract: Qualification Items Tab The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Adding or Editing a Qualification Item
Url.Abstract: Adding or Editing a Qualification Item The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using the Qualifications List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Qualifications List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Assign Query Condition
Url.Abstract: Assigning Query Conditions When you add a field to the Query Builder Conditions tab, the Assign Condition dialog box appears for that field.

Url.Title: Boolean Field Format Strings
Url.Abstract: Boolean Field Format Strings The format string to customize a Boolean string depends on the result desired. Enter the Truevalue / Falsevalue. It must be composed of alphanumeric characters and include a / between the true and false entries. True always takes precedence over false. The default format of FormatType ftBoolean is Yes/No.

Url.Title: Reordering Conditional Statements
Url.Abstract: Reordering a Conditional Statement If a query contains multiple conditional statements, you can move any statement up or down to change the order in which the conditions are applied to the query.

Url.Title: Currency and Phone Field Format Strings
Url.Abstract: Currency and Phone Field Format Strings and Phone Strings The table below lists the format string options for currency and phone number fields.

Url.Title: Date/Time Field Format Strings
Url.Abstract: Date/Time Field Format Strings The table below lists the format string options for date/time fields, but not date/time separators.

Url.Title: Date/Time Separators
Url.Abstract: Date/Time Separators The table below lists the date/time separators. Separator Description / Displays the date separator character given by the DateSeparator global variable.

Url.Title: Fixed Field Format Strings
Url.Abstract: Fixed Field Format Strings The table below lists the format string options for fixed fields. Valid string formats depend on the format type you select.

Url.Title: Format String
Url.Abstract: Format String Use a format string to format the data displayed in the query. First, select the format type. Then, type a format string to modify the format type you selected. The valid options depend on the format type you select. A format string must begin with a % sign and end with a format type character:

Url.Title: Format Type
Url.Abstract: Format Type You can select any of the following format types. Select To Number Format a field as a decimal number.

Url.Title: Grouping Conditional Statements
Url.Abstract: Grouping Conditional Statements In an advanced database query, it may be necessary to not only use multiple conditions, but also to group those conditions together so that more complex searches can be performed.

Url.Title: Hidden Fields
Url.Abstract: Hidden Fields Some fields are set to be hidden fields in the Database Manager. Hidden fields can be displayed but are not visible by default in the Query Builder.

Url.Title: Integer Field Format Strings
Url.Abstract: Integer Field Format Strings The table below lists the format string options for integer fields. Valid string formats depend on the format type you select.

Url.Title: Query Builder Field Type Conventions
Url.Abstract: Query Builder Field Type Conventions Each field type is represented by a symbol. The field type determines the operators available.

Url.Title: Query Builder Statement Connectors
Url.Abstract: Query Builder Statement Connectors Use connectors to indicate the end of the final conditional statement and how to interpret multiple conditional statements.

Url.Title: Query Builder Statement Operators
Url.Abstract: Query Builder Statement Operators When you add a conditional statement, you must select an operator. The operator is used to determine whether or not a record meets the criteria defined in a conditional statement. When you add a conditional statement, the default operator and other available operators depend on the field type.

Url.Title: Time Zone Field Format Strings
Url.Abstract: Time Zone Field Format Strings The table below lists the format string options for Time Zone fields. Valid string formats depend on the format type you select.

Url.Title: Use "Not" in a Conditional Statement
Url.Abstract: Using "Not" in a Conditional Statement You can insert NOT in front of a conditional statement or a group of conditional statements. If NOT is inserted in front of a group of conditional statements, it applies to all conditional statements within that group.

Url.Title: What are Virtual Server-Side Cursors (VSSC)
Url.Abstract: What are Virtual Server-Side Cursors (VSSC) Virtual Server-Side Cursors (VSSC) are designed to improve performance and memory usage for large groups in the Groups and List views in the Sage SalesLogix client.

Url.Title: Width specifier
Url.Abstract: Width Specifier A width specifier sets the minimum field width for a formatted field. If the minimum field width is not filled, it will be padded with blanks added in front of the value unless a left justification specifier is used.

Url.Title: Adding a Global Join
Url.Abstract: Adding a Global Join System Administrator Only A global join is permanent and exists from session to session in the Query Builder data tree structure. Be very careful when creating global joins. You can inadvertently create a global join that causes severe performance problems.

Url.Title: Adding a Local Join
Url.Abstract: Adding a Local Join A local join is temporary and only exists in the Query Builder for one session. The object using the resulting query will hold the properties of this local join while it is in use.

Url.Title: Argument index specifier
Url.Abstract: Argument Index Specifier The argument index specifier sets the current argument list index to a specified value. The first argument's index is 0. This is used to format the same argument multiple times.

Url.Title: Assigning a Query Layout
Url.Abstract: Assigning a Query Layout Use the Assign Query Layout dialog box to specify the appearance of each column of data (or field) in the query.

Url.Title: Calculation Alias
Url.Abstract: Calculation Alias Enter a name to be used in the calculation. It cannot contain any spaces or symbols. When the calculated field is used in constructing a plugin or query, this name is displayed in the list of available fields. This is a required field. You will be unable to finish creating any calculated field unless this has been set.

Url.Title: Types of Calculated Fields
Url.Abstract: Types of Calculated Fields There are two types of calculations: string and numeric. When you build a calculated field using strings (alphanumeric values), you concatenate, or connect, the values together to create one value. Numeric fields cannot be used in a string. When you build a calculated field using one or more numeric fields, you perform a mathematical operation (adding, subtracting, multiplying or dividing) on the values of each field to create a new value. You can also use constants in numeric calculations. Fields that are not numeric (such as strings) cannot be used in numeric calculations.

Url.Title: Caption Alignment
Url.Abstract: Caption Alignment Select an alignment for the labels on each column header. The options are Left, Right, and Center. The default is Left.

Url.Title: Cascade Options
Url.Abstract: Cascade Options Select To Delete Delete the selected record and any dependent records. For example, if a user is deleted from the USERINFO table, the associated records in the USERPROFILE table will also be deleted.

Url.Title: Select a Condition Value
Url.Abstract: Selecting a Condition Value When you complete the Assign Condition dialog box while setting up a condition in the Query Builder, a Browse button appears next to the Value is box. If you click Browse, the Select Values dialog box displays all of the values in the database for the field you selected. Select a value and click OK.

Url.Title: Data Relationships
Url.Abstract: Data Relationships A relational database contains multiple tables. The structure of the database is defined by how these tables relate to one another. Since data is acquired based on table relationships, it is important to understand the relationship between tables before adding custom tables and fields to the database. It is also helpful when creating queries for lookups, groups, subscription rules or templates, and so on.

Url.Title: Delete a Global Join
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Global Join System Administrator Only A global join is permanent and exists from session to session in the Query Builder data tree structure. You cannot delete predefined global joins (system joins).

Url.Title: Edit a Global Join
Url.Abstract: Editing a Global Join System Administrator Only A global join is permanent and exists from session to session in the Query Builder data tree structure. With predefined global joins (system joins), you can only edit the Join Type, Visibility, and Cascade Type options.

Url.Title: ID fields in tables
Url.Abstract: ID Fields in Tables Every table has at least one ID field that is used to ensure that each record in the table is unique. When a record is added to the ACCOUNT table, a value is automatically entered in the AccountID field. Each time a record is added, a value is generated based on information in the key file.

Url.Title: Inner joins
Url.Abstract: Inner Joins An inner join is the default type for local joins. Use an inner join to include only records where the values in the fields you are joining are the same in both the Parent and Child tables.

Url.Title: Join Example
Url.Abstract: Join Example The example for Inner, Left, and Right joins use the OPPORTUNITY and ACTIVITY tables to demonstrate each type of join. The OPPORTUNITY and ACTIVITY tables each contain the OPPORTUNITYID field. Opportunities can exist without associated activities. Activities can exist that are not related to an opportunity. Each join example uses the same opportunity and activity records to demonstrate that different types of joins result in different records being selected. The join results records are shown in a separate column in each of the three types of joins.

Url.Title: Join Types
Url.Abstract: Join Types Inner - Include only records where the joined fields from both tables are equal. Example

Url.Title: Left joins
Url.Abstract: Left Joins A left join is the default type for global joins. Use a left join to include all the records in the Parent table that meet the selection criteria and only those records in the Child table where the values in the fields you are joining are equal.

Url.Title: Left justification indicator
Url.Abstract: Left Justification Indicator A left justification indicator is a "-" character that precedes a width specifier. It essentially tells the width to pad any fields shorter than the minimum width after the value instead of the default, before the value.

Url.Title: Operators
Url.Abstract: Operators There are four mathematical operators in calculated fields: add, subtract, multiply, and divide. Use brackets to group parts of your calculations. Only numeric fields (such as integer fields) can be used in numeric calculations. If an operator is used in a string-calculated field, it will act as just another character. Operators in string calculated fields will not perform any operations.

Url.Title: Precision specifier
Url.Abstract: Precision Specifier A precision specifier determines how many decimal places to use in a floating point integer. In Sage SalesLogix, the default precision specifier is 2 decimal places. However, not all field types support unlimited decimal place storage and use accordingly.

Url.Title: Example: Using Query Builder to Create a Group
Url.Abstract: Example: Using the Query Builder to Create a Group The following example explains how to create a group of all primary contacts who work in the Sales department of their companies.

Url.Title: Selecting Tables and Fields
Url.Abstract: Selecting Tables and Fields You can add a field to display in a query. To select a table Select a table from the left side of the Query Builder. If necessary, click the plus sign to expand the list of tables.

Url.Title: Right Joins
Url.Abstract: Right Joins Use a right join to include all the records in the Child table that meet the selection criteria and only those rows in the Parent table where the values in the fields you are joining are equal.

Url.Title: Show a Global Join
Url.Abstract: Showing a Global Join In Sage SalesLogix, a number of global joins are set up for you. However, not all of them are visible when the Query Builder is opened due to space constraints. If one of these joins already exists when you are using the Query Builder to select data, you should use it rather than creating a new join.

Url.Title: Table Relationship Types
Url.Abstract: Table Relationship Types The parent table determines the table relationship. For example, when the CONTACT table is the parent table, it has a One to One relationship with the Account table. However, when the ACCOUNT table is the parent table, the relationship is One to Many. In the Example column, parent table names are in italics.

Url.Title: Text Alignment
Url.Abstract: Text Alignment Select an alignment for the text contained within the selected column of data. The options are Left, Right, and Center. The default is Left.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting: Query Builder is Slow to Respond
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting: Query Builder is Slow to Respond System Administrator Only If the Query Builder is taking a long time to respond, there may be recursive joins which can be removed. An example of a recursive join is:

Url.Title: Use Value as a Literal
Url.Abstract: Use Value as a Literal The Use Value as a Literal selection, on the Assign Condition dialog box, places text in the query exactly as it appears in the Value is box. In most cases, you should not select this option so that the Query Builder can determine the correct SQL statement. However, in some instances, advanced users may want to type specific text that should be written directly to the SQL statement.

Url.Title: Visibility Options
Url.Abstract: Visibility Options Select To Always Always display the join in the Query Builder tree view. Allow Display the join the Query Builder tree view only if the user selects the joined field, right clicks, and selects Global Join to (name of join) from the shortcut menu.

Url.Title: Sage SalesLogix Personal Web Server
Url.Abstract: Sage SalesLogix Personal Web Server The Personal Web Server hosts the Sage SalesLogix portals on a Remote Client computer.

Url.Title: Understanding the Sage SalesLogix Offline Web Client
Url.Abstract: Understanding the Sage SalesLogix Offline Web Client Offline Web Client Remote users only The Offline Web Client functions like the Sage SalesLogix Remote Client except that users connect to their local database using the Web Client. The Offline Web Client allows you to work offline without an active internet connection.

Url.Title: Subscription and Security
Url.Abstract: Subscription and Security Remote users only You can use subscription to select, or subscribe to, accounts you use on a regular basis and want to store on your local database. Using subscription minimizes your database size and the time required to synchronize updated information to the main office database. You and your system administrator can establish what accounts you need to subscribe to.

Url.Title: What's New
Url.Abstract: What's New Use What's New to see a list of all recent changes to information you can access. This view presents a list of all new or modified accounts, contacts, leads, opportunities, activities, notes, history, contract, defects and returns. You can only see information your security allows you to access.

Url.Title: What's New for Disconnected Web Users
Url.Abstract: What's New for Offline Web Client Users Offline Web Client Remote users only Use the What's New view to track additions, updates, and deletions to your local database, and to subscribe to accounts. What's New information is organized on a series of tabs.

Url.Title: Understanding Conflict Resolution
Url.Abstract: Understanding Conflict Resolution Sage SalesLogix Network and Remote users may both need to make changes to the same record. A Network user’s changes are directly applied to the main office database. Remote users change their local database, and synchronize with the main office, which then applies their changes.

Url.Title: What Is Synchronization?
Url.Abstract: What Is Synchronization? Remote users only If your company has Remote users who cannot connect to a central computing environment, such as a wide area network or on-line system, the changes they make to their database will be inconsistent with the information in their database and the Host database. Synchronization reconciles these changes, applies changes to the workgroup database, and creates files that remote clients can retrieve to update remote databases.

Url.Title: Viewing Condition Formulas
Url.Abstract: Viewing Condition Formulas Administrators familiar with Extended Markup Language (XML) or SQL can view the report condition formulas to assist them in troubleshooting. This option can be helpful for troubleshooting.

Url.Title: Viewing and Printing Detail View Reports
Url.Abstract: Viewing and Printing Detail View Reports Some detail views have a detail report that you can view or print. You can view and print detail reports from the Contact, Account, Opportunity, Ticket, and Defect detail views.

Url.Title: Filtering Data in Reports
Url.Abstract: Filtering Data in Reports When you run a report, you can filter the data it includes. Filters are comprised of one or more conditions. For example, you can set conditions to include only specific accounts or groups in a report. You can save filters in order to quickly apply them each time you run a report. If required, Administrators can view the report condition formulas for troubleshooting purposes.

Url.Title: Setting Report Prompts
Url.Abstract: Setting Report Prompts Some reports include prompts that you must select responses for. To set report prompts

Url.Title: Sharing Report Filters
Url.Abstract: Sharing Report Filters You can share your report filters with other users. When you do so, the filter is made public for everyone to use, however, only the creator of a filter can change it.

Url.Title: Resource Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Resource Information Boxes The resource information boxes contain information about the selected resource. You can edit or delete the information as needed.

Url.Title: Using the Resource List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Resource List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Return Comments Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Return Comments Tab Use this tab for all internal notes related to a return. To add comments

Url.Title: Using the Defects Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Defects Tab The Defects tab on the Ticket and Return Detail views displays all associated defects. Use this tab to add or remove an association with a defect.

Url.Title: Deleting a Return
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Return If you have the appropriate privileges, you can delete a Return. To delete Open the Return Detail view.

Url.Title: Editing a Return
Url.Abstract: Editing a Return Use the Return Detail view to edit information for an existing return. To edit Open the Return Detail view.

Url.Title: Return Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Return Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Using the Shipped Product Boxes
Url.Abstract: Using the Shipped Product Boxes Use these boxes to enter information about the product being shipped to the customer as part of the return.

Url.Title: Return Ship To Details Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Return Ship To Details Tab Use this tab to add information about replacement products being shipped to the customer as part of the selected return. The customer's information is added from the return information, but you can select a different contact to receive the shipped replacement parts.

Url.Title: Using Return Details Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Return Details Tab Use this tab to view information about the contact returning the item or to associate or disassociate assets as part of the return.

Url.Title: Adding or Editing a Custom Product
Url.Abstract: Adding or Editing a Custom Product You can add or edit a custom product from the Sales Order Product tab.

Url.Title: Adding/Editing Sales Order Products
Url.Abstract: Adding Sales Order Products You can add products using the Add Product view or add custom products using the Products tab grid. Use the Lookup to narrow the list of products and packages. After you add a product, you can edit the product details, such as the discount, adjusted price and quantity.

Url.Title: Sales Order Billing and Shipping Tab
Url.Abstract: Sales Order Billing and Shipping Tab The Bill/Ship Address tab appears on the Sales Order Detail View. Use this tab to manage the billing and shipping addresses for a sales order.

Url.Title: Deleting a Sales Order
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Sales Order You can remove sales orders from an opportunity at any time. To delete Find the sales order you want to delete.

Url.Title: Editing Product Information
Url.Abstract: Editing Product Information Use the Edit Sales Order Item dialog box to edit a sales order's product information.

Url.Title: Sales Order Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Sales Order Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description

Url.Title: Removing a Product from a Sales Order
Url.Abstract: Removing a Product from a Sales Order You can remove products from a sales order if a customer is no longer interested in the product, or the products were added by mistake. You can remove products from the Insert Sales Order dialog box or Sales Order Detail view. Deleting a product only removes the product's association with a particular sales order. The product is not deleted from the database.

Url.Title: Sales Order Products Tab
Url.Abstract: Sales Order Products Tab Use this view to add, edit, or remove products associated with the sales order.

Url.Title: Editing Sales Order Snapshot Details
Url.Abstract: Editing Sales Order Snapshot Details Use this dialog box to edit the tax rate, shipping or discount of a sales order.

Url.Title: Sales Order Snapshot
Url.Abstract: Sales Order Snapshot You can view information about the selected sales order's value in the Sales Order Snapshot in the top section of the Sales Order Detail view. You can edit the information as needed.

Url.Title: Sales Orders Tab
Url.Abstract: Sales Orders Tab This feature is not available if your implementation includes Accounting Integration. Accounting Integration users can view associated sales orders on the Accounting Sales Orders tab on the Account Detail view .

Url.Title: Sales Process Snapshot
Url.Abstract: Sales Process Snapshot This functionality is only available when the appropriate license is installed. For complete information about licensing, see the Sage SalesLogix Planning Guide.

Url.Title: Sales Process Tab
Url.Abstract: Sales Process Tab This functionality is only available when the appropriate license is installed. For complete information about licensing, see the Sage SalesLogix Planning Guide.

Url.Title: Actions that Trigger Sage SalesLogix Events
Url.Abstract: Actions that Trigger Events in Sage SalesLogix The system administrator manages the actions that trigger events.

Url.Title: Using SpeedSearch Filter By Options
Url.Abstract: Using SpeedSearch Filter By Options The Filter By options are made available by clicking Advanced in the SpeedSearch Client. These filters allow you to limit the results to records that meet specific criteria.

Url.Title: Previewing SpeedSearch Results
Url.Abstract: Previewing SpeedSearch Results After you perform a search and select an item, use the Preview to view detailed information from the item.

Url.Title: Viewing SpeedSearch Results
Url.Abstract: Viewing SpeedSearch Results The Results tab displays a list of items matching your search criteria. As you select each item, it appears on the Preview tab. Clicking a link in the Results tab will either take you to the record's detail view, or will open the activity or history details dialog box.

Url.Title: Using the Standard Problem Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Standard Problem Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Standard Problem Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Standard Problem Information Boxes The standard problem boxes contain information about the selected problem. You can edit or delete the information as needed.

Url.Title: Using the Standard Problem List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Standard Problem List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Managing Standard Problems
Url.Abstract: Managing Standard Problems The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: What Are Standard Problems and Resolutions?
Url.Abstract: What Are Standard Problems and Resolutions? A standard problem is an issue in your product that generates communication from multiple customers. Your call center may frequently receive calls about problems that are similar. Use Standard Problems to record descriptions of these problems, and Standard Resolutions to store proven ways they can be resolved. Once standard problems and resolutions are established, they can be used to supplement a ticket description or used as the ticket resolution.

Url.Title: Standard Problem Standard Resolutions Tab
Url.Abstract: Standard Problem Standard Resolutions Tab The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using the Resolution Detail View
Url.Abstract: Using the Resolution Detail View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Using the Standard Resolutions List View
Url.Abstract: Using the Standard Resolutions List View The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Adding or Editing a Standard Problem Resolution
Url.Abstract: Adding or Editing a Standard Problem Resolution The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Standard Resolution Standard Problems Tab
Url.Abstract: Standard Resolution Standard Problems Tab The system administrator and users with the appropriate role can access these features.

Url.Title: Attaching or Removing Template Files
Url.Abstract: Attaching or Removing Template Files You can attach Windows files or Library files to a template. When the template is used in a mail merge, the attached files are automatically sent to the contact or lead. If the template containing the attachment is copied, the attachment is copied also. You can also remove an attachment from a template.

Url.Title: Copying a Template
Url.Abstract: Copying a Template You can copy private and public templates; however, when you copy a public template, it will be saved as a private template.

Url.Title: Creating a Template
Url.Abstract: Creating a Template Using the template editor, you can create a private template. To create a new template

Url.Title: Creating a Proposal
Url.Abstract: Creating a Proposal You can use Mail Merge to create sales proposals. To create a proposal On the Write menu, select Templates.

Url.Title: Customizing Insert SLX Field Menu
Url.Abstract: Customizing Insert SLX Field Menu Sage SalesLogix allows you to customize the fields on the Insert SLX Field menu. You can set the format type and string for the field, insert a separator, remove a field, or move a field up or down in the list.

Url.Title: Deleting a Template
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Template You can only delete private templates that you own. However, if the template has been released to others and is shared, your Sage SalesLogix administrator should remove the template.

Url.Title: Deleting Merge Fields
Url.Abstract: Deleting Merge Fields You can remove merge fields from templates from within the E-mail, Letter, or Fax Template Editor.

Url.Title: Editing a Template
Url.Abstract: Editing a Template You can edit private or public templates; you can edit a public template, if you copy the template and save it as a private template.

Url.Title: Editing Columns
Url.Abstract: Editing Columns The option to edit columns is recommended for Advanced Users only. When editing the columns in the Edit Columns dialog box, the column information must be manually entered based on the SQL used. There is no automatic synchronization between the SQL and the column information. If no column information is provided, the columns will be formatted using the default settings and the field names will be used for the column captions. If more columns are defined than are contained in the SQL, then the extra column information will be discarded. If fewer columns are defined than are contained in the SQL, then the remaining columns will be formatted using the default settings but will have no caption.

Url.Title: Editing Merge Fields
Url.Abstract: Editing Merge Fields You can use the Mail Merge Field Editor to edit new and existing merge fields. You can view the template merge fields in the list view and your edit options in the edit pane. You can also remove merge fields from the template by selecting the Remove From Template button on the toolbar.

Url.Title: Editing SQL
Url.Abstract: Editing SQL Editing SQL is recommended for Advanced Users only. You can use the Edit SQL dialog box to create and edit SQL statements for mail merge fields. You can use the Edit menu or toolbar to Cut, Copy, Paste, or Delete text. You can also insert parameters into an SQL statement.

Url.Title: Editing SQL Image Fields
Url.Abstract: Editing SQL Image Fields You can use the Mail Merge Field Editor to edit new and existing SQL Image merge fields. When you select an SQL Image field from the list view, the edit options will display in the edit pane.

Url.Title: Editing SQL Text Fields
Url.Abstract: Editing SQL Text Fields You can use the Mail Merge Field Editor to edit new and existing SQL Text merge fields. When you select an SQL Text field from the list view, the edit options will display in the edit pane.

Url.Title: Email Options
Url.Abstract: Email Options When creating an e-mail template, you can set options for the e-mail message(s) you want to send. For example, as the administrator, you may need to send out a mass e-mail on behalf of your sales team from a generic company address (i.e., salesteam@company.com). You can have the Reply To field in the outbound e-mail populated dynamically during the mail merge so that when recipients reply to the e-mail they have received, it is automatically addressed to their assigned account manager.

Url.Title: Inserting Special Fields
Url.Abstract: Inserting Special Fields The option to insert special fields is available to Advanced Users only. You can click the Insert Special Field button of the E-mail, Fax, or Letter Template Editor to insert a new opportunity product table, SQL statement, or custom mail merge field.

Url.Title: Managing and Selecting Templates
Url.Abstract: Managing and Selecting Templates You can use the Manage Templates or Select a Template dialog box to access the Public and Private templates that are available to you.

Url.Title: Releasing a Private Template
Url.Abstract: Releasing a Private Template If releasing a Private Template to another user, it is recommended that you copy the template first, then release the copied template to the other user. That way, you will still have the Private template in your list.

Url.Title: Selecting a Sage SalesLogix User
Url.Abstract: Selecting a Sage SalesLogix User The Select User dialog box is used when you are: Creating or copying a template, and you need to select an owner for a template

Url.Title: Setting Merge Field Format
Url.Abstract: Setting Merge Field Format Use the Format SalesLogix Field dialog box to set the format type and format string for a Sage SalesLogix merge field.

Url.Title: Setting or Updating the Properties for a Template
Url.Abstract: Setting or Updating the Properties for a Template You can set or update the properties for a private or public template when creating, editing, or copying a template. If you are editing or copying a template, some property settings will default to the settings for the selected template; however, you can change these settings if desired.

Url.Title: Using Sage SalesLogix Merge Fields
Url.Abstract: Using Sage SalesLogix Merge Fields The Insert SLX Field menu contains the most commonly used Sage SalesLogix merge fields. However, when creating or editing a template, if you need a Sage SalesLogix field that is not in the menu, you can use select More SLX Fields to access all the Sage SalesLogix merge fields. In addition, you can add a field to the menu, and customize the menu.

Url.Title: Using the E-mail Editor
Url.Abstract: Using the E-mail Editor With the E-mail Editor window you can create a new e-mail template or edit an existingtemplate. Like the Letter and Fax Editors, the E-mail Editor contains a Sage SalesLogix toolbar which give you access to the special template functions as well as many Microsoft Word features.

Url.Title: Using the Fax Editor
Url.Abstract: Using the Fax Editor With the Fax Editor window you can create a new Fax template or edit an existing template. Like the E-Mail and Letter Editors, the Fax Editor contains a Sage SalesLogix toolbar which give you access to the special template functions as well as many Microsoft Word features.

Url.Title: Using the Letter Editor
Url.Abstract: Using the Letter Editor With the E-mail Editor window you can create a new Letter template or edit an existing template. Like the E-mail and Fax Editors, the Letter Editor contains a Sage SalesLogix toolbar which give you access to the special template functions as well as many Microsoft Word features.

Url.Title: Using the Template Editor
Url.Abstract: Using the Template Editor With the Template Editor, you can create a new template or edit an existing template. The editor contains a Sage SalesLogix toolbar which gives you access to the special template functions as well as many Microsoft Word features. The features available depend on whether the type of template you are editing is a Letter, an E-mail or a Fax.

Url.Title: Adding and Editing Ticket Activities
Url.Abstract: Adding and Editing Ticket Activities Use this view to add a new activity for work done on the ticket or to edit/update an existing activity. Ticket Activities enable you to track the time, the types of tasks, and any associated costs involved in resolving a ticket. Activities are recorded by activity type and charge rate and are used for billing the customer against their service contracts.You can set up future (follow-up) activities for yourself or another user.

Url.Title: Account Service Information
Url.Abstract: Account Service Information The Account Service Information dialog box provides account, ticket, contact, asset, and contract information to help you understand the relationship of the person requesting assistance to his or her account. You can also use this dialog box to determine the type of assistance you can provide according to the account's service contract.

Url.Title: Ticket Activity Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Ticket Activity Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Ticket Information Boxes
Url.Abstract: Ticket Information Boxes The following table describes the default information boxes. Box Description/Action

Url.Title: Using the Returns Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Returns Tab The Returns tab on the Account and Ticket Detail views lists all returns for the selected record.

Url.Title: Sending an E-mail Message from a Ticket
Url.Abstract: Sending an E-mail Message from a Ticket You can send an e-mail message to a customer or another Sage SalesLogix user while adding a new ticket or from the Ticket Detail view. The e-mail can provide ticket information; to inform others including the customer that you opened the ticket, or to ask questions to help resolve the issue.

Url.Title: Editing Ticket Activity Parts
Url.Abstract: Editing Ticket Activity Parts Use this view to manage parts in relationship to the ticket activity. To edit

Url.Title: Using the Defects Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Defects Tab The Defects tab on the Ticket and Return Detail views displays all associated defects. Use this tab to add or remove an association with a defect.

Url.Title: Using the Ticket Activities Tab
Url.Abstract:
Using the Ticket Activities Tab The Ticket Activities tab shows all activities associated with working on and resolving the ticket. Use the Ticket Activities tab to add a new activity for work done on the ticket or to edit/update an existing activity. You can set up future (follow-up) activities for yourself or another user.
You can click a column heading to sort the list according to that column. By default, the newest Ticket Activity (according to date and time) appears at the top of the list.

Url.Title: Ticket Activity Parts
Url.Abstract: Ticket Activity Parts Use this view to manage parts in relationship to the ticket activity. How Do I? Open the Ticket Activity Parts Tab

Url.Title: Ticket Comments Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Ticket Comments Tab Use the Comments text box for all internal notes, troubleshooting steps, or other important information related to the ticket.

Url.Title: Ticket Details Tab
Url.Abstract: Ticket Detail View Details Tab The Ticket Details tab contains the Subject, problem Description, and problem Resolution text boxes. Use these boxes when describing the problem and how it was resolved.

Url.Title: Ticket Journal Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Ticket Journal Tab The Journal tab contains a historical log of actions, such as changes made to information boxes for a ticket. The system automatically posts some of the information in the Journal boxes on the tab; users cannot change that information. A customer service user or manager can use the Journal tab to track and measure customer response time and effort.

Url.Title: Ticket Related Assets Tab
Url.Abstract: Using the Ticket Related Assets Tab Use the Related Assets tab on the Ticket Detail view to see all assets associated with the selected ticket and to associate and disassociate other related assets to the ticket.

Url.Title: Using Punch In and Punch Out
Url.Abstract: Using Punch In and Punch Out The Punch In and Punch Out function enables you to track the time spent assisting a customer for each ticket. When you click the Punch In button on a ticket's detail view, Sage SalesLogix begins timing the activity. When you are finished, you can click Punch Out. Sage SalesLogix stops timing the activity and adds an activity record to the Ticket Activities tab for the ticket.

Url.Title: Attachments Open as Compressed Folder
Url.Abstract: Attachments Open as Compressed Folder Problem: When I open an attachment I get a message that the attached file is a "Compressed (zipped) Folder".

Url.Title: I Cannot Delete a User
Url.Abstract: I Cannot Delete a User Error message: Other users report to this user. This user cannot be deleted. Error message:

Url.Title: Why Can I Not Move this Contact?
Url.Abstract: Why Can I Not Move this Contact? You cannot move the last contact of an account if there are any open records that cannot move with the contact. These records include, attachments, literature requests, opportunities, sales orders, tickets, returns, and contracts.
